title: What is the role of clusters of images in creating a value system and how do they contribute to our psychological defense mechanisms?
first_phrase: In this text, the author explores the idea that clusters of images can create a value system or philosophy. The text delves into the effects of dissociation and repression of exhaustion, and how attempting obsessive-compulsively to understand can be a defense mechanism. The author also discusses the basic beliefs in obsessive-compulsive tendencies and how those beliefs can contribute to a resistance to experiencing what has occurred. As the text concludes, the author raises concerns about psychology's focus on stories and creating new stories, which may perpetuate the associational trance.
content: One is, if I can just understand it, the chaos will be organized. Two, if I find out what I did wrong, I can control it so that it will never happen again. Three, if I make or do it right this time, it won't happen again. In short, it is a resistance to what has occurred, and an associational tendency used as a survival mechanism. The tendency is if I could just understand this (fill in the blank), then somehow the chaos would disappear. In a short time the desire to understand becomes a defense against experiencing and not knowing, and is often the impetus and drive to type, characterize and diagnose people. Unfortunately, in psychology, they are dealing with stories and trying to get people to understand their stories. Then, in psychology the work often becomes to create (new) stories about the stories. Accumulating information, refraining, creating new stories about the stories, future pacing (the trance of futurizing)â€”all of this keeps the associational trance alive with the belief that if I do (fill in the blank), this will or will not happen again.
last_phrase: It's important to acknowledge that our desire to understand and control our past experiences can become a defense mechanism that prevents us from fully experiencing our present reality. While psychology may offer insights and tools for creating new stories about our past, the key to overcoming our associational trance lies in developing multi-dimensional awareness and learning to be present in the here and now. By understanding the biology behind our survival mechanisms and staying grounded in the present moment, we can break free from the patterns that keep us stuck in the past and embrace our full potential for growth and change.
